text: THE MAN has the look of Rainer Fassbinder and Geraldo Riv the same man; is of average build and has a wash of hair his forehead that looks quite foreign. He turns to the ri three times, as he is circling his car.
OUT THE WINDOW OF THE CAR, we see the boys again.
What's this guy want, think he  wants to party?
What's that mean? "Suck my dick?"  Does he want to suck my dick?
How the fuck do you know.
I've studied German, in prep  school.
You know, Scottie, I don't know  when to believe you.
THE MAN leans out the window of his car.
Gary leans into the man's car.
(speaks with a thick German  accent)  Excuse me. Can I speak to the young  man over there, with the blond hair,  ya?
Who, that kid there? You can't  talk with him now, he's asleep.
No, you can't wake him... he......  but, what about me? Don't you want  to talk with me? The man is not interested in talking to Gary. He shakes h no, bothered by Gary.
(speaking fluent German) Was willist du in Gottesname mit uns  Juenge?  Mach' es flar oder fanre  ab! (What in the hell do you want with  us young kids, be specific or get  out.)
(surprised) Du bisst sehr intelligent mit deinem  Aksent..  Fuer elnen Puppejunge. (You are very clever with an accent  like that.. for a street boy.) THE MAN IN THE CAR SPEEDS OFF.
INSIDE OF MIKE'S thoughts. He is flying over the city str above the Mercedes Benz, effortlessly hovering and gildin it, between the buildings.  Like a bird.
Mike wakes and looks at Scottie, who is talking to Gary.

The first time I met Scott, I had  a feeling he was a sort of comic  book hero. He was always saying  the right thing at the right  moment, and standing up for me  when there was no reason to. Look  at his face now, when the sunlight  shines off his lower lip, like it  is the face of some sort of  statue. Strong and soft at the  same time. I never could figure  out what Scott was doing here with  us on the street in the first  place, like he was on some sort of  crusade, to help the poor. Because  he really did come from a rich  Portland family. I know because he  brought me to his house one day  and showed me around. I mean, wow,  they were rich I They even had a  swimming pool. Scott's the only  kid that I had ever met that had a  swimming pool. I'd make a bet with  anybody right now, that Scott is a  saint or a hero, or some such  higher placed person. Meanwhile... Gary and Ray are talking. Ray, who is a Chicano street ki looking poetically off into the distance.
My father was a gaucho. But nobody  gonna find him. He killed a guy  and split. Nobody gonna find that  fuck. I never gonna find him.
Ray spits into the gutter and the spit drifts in a small made by the shop-owner who was washing his windows, down street and into drainage grating.
View of MIKE as he closes his eyes, oblivious to what is around him.
The music in a DISCO blares, at night, and all we can see Mike's face, sleeping. The disco MUSIC STOPS, and the lig up.
A broom passes by Mike's head.
Finally, THE MANAGER'S SHOES appear at his head.
What's wrong with him?  Passed  out?
Mike wakes up in a WARD ROOM BED in the daytime.
He looks around him. The room has a lot of light, windows practically on all sides of the room. There are other DET and women in other beds. Mike gets up and starts to walk he is wearing a gown.
Excuse me. Are you all right?
If you're going to leave us, it's  okay, but we need you to sign out,  and you'll need to get your  clothes from downstairs. MIKE
Oh. Yeah. (he pauses and looks  around the place.) Do you live  here? NURSE
Why... no. But sometimes I feel  like I do.
The nurse walks him over to a clipboard on a desk. Mike s board, and she gives him a receipt.
That's Just a receipt. if you  don't want it. You can throw it  away. That's what most people do  with it.

Then we cut to Mike's face at night. As his eyes open he look around him, a little dazed, trying to figure where h see he is under a store awning. A lot of fog is rolling a the street. A twenty-eight-year-old woman stops in a Mercedes Benz se similar to the one that the German man was driving. She m Mike to get inside the car.
Dazed, Mike looks at the car, then responds.
This chick is living in a new car  ad.
Inside a hallway entrance to the woman's home. Mike and t take off their Jackets.
This is like a dream. A pretty  woman never picks me up.
Mike begins to caress her arm.
They Don't? Well. I Don't see why  not...
Mike follows the woman into her...
Living room where sit Scottie and Gary on a plush sofa. M them.
Oh... Mike sits down in an easy chair next to the sofa.
You men make yourselves  comfortable, and I'll be right  back. There're cokes in the  refrigerator - help yourself. They watch her go.
She's cool. She Just likes to have  three guys, 'cause - it takes her  a little while to get warmed up.  It's normal. Nothing kinky. MIKE
Mike looks around the room. Gary leans closer to Mike.
Hey, did you get into that Van  Halen concert last night? MIKE
I've never been to a concert,  dude.

Interior of the Woman's bedroom. Mike undresses. He waits side of the bed and takes a last drag on a cigarette and puts it out. Then the woman arrives. lets d negligee and approaches Mike like an EARTH MOTHER, slowly breasted, warm, comforting.
As she approaches, Mike begins to see a familiar face. He upset when he looks into her eyes.  And he begins to  spasmodically shake then he grows sleepy, and finally, as upon him, he passes out.
Outside, Gary and Scottie struggle with Mike's body.
They plop Mike down on the corner, under a streetlight, f arms under his stomach and bend him over so he is sitting against the light pole.
(putting money into his pocket) He  always does this! I'm surprised he  makes money at all. GARY
How do we tell if he's okay?
He's not dead. He's Just passed  out. It's a condition. It's called  narcolepsy.
Scared the shit out of her. What  causes it. Sex?
Where are we going to take him?
Scott lifts Mike's body up and carries him to a soft carp grass on the edge of a lawn. Scott looks around to see if okay. Then he speaks to Mike even though he is asleep.

Hey, little brother. You stay  here, and when you wake up, Just  come back into town. I'll be there  waiting for you. I figure you're  going to be safer here in this  comfy neighborhood than in the  city. I grew up in a neighborhood  like this. It'll be safe here. Scottie hides a tear. Then he takes his Jacket off and pu over Mike, then leaves him there.
Mike's face is lying down with his nose pressed against a ground in the daytime.

He wakes up, stands, makes his way up a slope and out to street. He brushes himself off as the Mercedes Benz shows again. Mike recognizes it, and walks up to the window of It is the MAN, though, not the lady. The Man speaks with accent - and he is about 35 years old. HIS NAME IS HANS.
Mike brushes himself off and walks down the road, thinkin the guy is weird.
Hans drives alongside Mike in his car.
Do you want a lift? Bill?
Hey, isn't this the lady's car?
Is Alena a friend of yours?  She's  a friend of mine. Any friend of  Alena's is a friend of mine. Do  you want to be my friend?
Get in and I'll take you  someplace. Yes? Where do you want  to go? Mike doesn't respond, and walks on.
He pauses a moment, and looks at the houses in the neighb He looks down the street and can see Hans stopped in his guy gets out, and leans against the car.
This guy is a pervert. I can tell.

head_text.subj: THE HOUSES LINE THE STREET, EACH WITH A LITTLE CALIFORNIA
GARDEN. MIKE CAN SEE ALL THE ROOFS OF THE HOUSES LIFT OFF
THE FURNITURE INSIDE EACH HOUSE FLY OUT AND CIRCLE IN TH
MIKE GETS THE JITTERS AND PASSES OUT.
THE MERCEDES BENZ PULLS UP NEXT TO HIS HEAD, WHICH IS NOW

text: When Mike wakes up he is in Scottie's arms. They sit unde statue in a park. The statue is of two Indians pointing o across the horizon, and on the base of the statue is writ Coming of the White Man.
Mike looks at Scott and then at the new surroundings.  At the Broadway Cafe Mike bites into a hamburger.
That German guy. Hans. He brought  you downtown, you were passed out.  He said he was heading to  Portland, so I asked him for a  ride.
I don't remember any German guy.
How much do you make off me while  I'm sleeping?
Just a ride, Mike. I don't make  anything. What, you think that I  sell your body while you are  asleep.
Scott sips from a coffee cup.
No, Mike. I'm on your side.
He puts down the cup. Mike knows Scottie always tells the Mike is a little embarrassed, that he has maybe offended honor.
Gary's up here somewhere. He left  three days ago, he flew up with  some John.
Exotic. Have you seen your dad?
I'd visit my dad, if he was here.
I have to take care of you.
That lady. She looked like. My  mother.
Is that why you passed out?
Yeah. I mean. I don't know. She  really looked like my mother. I  must have been imagining things.
The Broadway Cafe is beginning to pick up in business.  T where Scott and Mike sit is in front of a large window, a semi-circular in shape. Scottie spies Gary across the str
He bounds up out of his chair and Mike watches him as he the door, kicks it open and yells to Gary.
Gary sees Scott and runs across the street.
Later in the BROADWAY CAFE, there are other street kids h around the table.
Scott has his arm around a girl named DENISE, who has a l make up on and long stringy hair and who carries a teddy Denise is crying and Scott is consoling her.

It was almost as if Scott was on  some sort of crusade or mission,  when you checked him out.  He  could make you feel good right at  the very time that you felt so  bad. I remember there were many  times that I had been sobbing in  Scott's arms and he was helping me  out too. He was the great  protector of us all, and the great  planner. He gave us hope in the  future. Even though there was no  future. There must have been real  trouble at home, though, for Scott  not to want to visit his father. Scott strokes Denise's hair adoringly and gives her a kis now and then.
Mike looks across the table at CARL, a skinny kid with bl and a large floppy sports cap, and GARY, who is talking w

That's Carl. He's always around  the Broadway, he didn't run away  from home like a lot of these kids  did. He had a mom, and no dad, at  least they didn't know where he  was. And one day, he came home to  the apartment where they lived,  and there was no mom anymore  either. He didn't know where she  went. That was sir months ago. MARY, an older, wiser street prostitute who is chain smok cigarettes.

That's Mary over there. She was a  mean old chick. She was maybe  thirty now. Old, old. Somebody  once told me that in the past,  Mary had this enemy, a chick that  had turned her in. And Mary had  gone off and kicked this chick to  death right in the street in front  of everybody. I don't know if it's  true, but I watched out, Just in  case. I was afraid of Mary. And  everyone else was too.
Mary takes a drag from her cigarette and blows smoke in M face.
Scott notices this. But he attends to Denise's problems.

(as he coughs) This was our little round table, a  point around which everything else  revolved. It was our "center." It was  like our home. Our living room. Not  everyone was the best of friends, but  everyone knew everyone else, and we  kind of stuck together.
Mike on the street. He watches as a man carrying a large tin cans, crosses at a crosswalk. Mike steps up to him an walking. His name is MARTY.
Is that you Mike? Hey, what's new  with you? You look pretty good.
How many you got so far today?
I reckon that I picked up about  twenty-three bucks so far with  these cans, and some I got stashed  back in the bushes. You know the  old hiding place?
Don't tell anybody, though. Just  between you and me. You need a  place to stay? MIKE
I always need a place to stay,  dude. MARTY
Yeah, well, I'm under the bridge.  You can Join me if you like. MIKE
Yeah, I think I'll rooftop it  tonight. I'm hanging with a  friend. MARTY
Am I walking too fast for you?
No, but I'll see you around. See  you under the bridge.
Mike stops walking with the guy and he splits down the st a fast clip.
Inside the BROADWAY CAFE, Mike smokes a cigarette at the table and watches Gary and Carl playing keepaway with Den teddy bear. Denise is swearing, using profanities that ar unusual for a girl.
Night. Mike walks through a dark wet troubled inner-city and on the other side, there is a parked car. In the car man in his 40's, bestial, good looking but overweight. He his car horn at Mike.
Mike pauses, lights a cigarette coolly and walks to the c leans in the window.
The man is naked in the background standing In front of a in a motel bathroom, as Mike sits naked on a bed in front t.v. set laughing at the show that is on.
We see various still compositions of the two making love.
Afield. Day. Two figures cross the field. One is Bob Pige man in his fifties, and the other, his manservant, Budd. of his girth, Bob has problems crossing the field.
Jesus. ..the things we've seen...  do you remember a thing since we  moved from graffiti bridge?
Above the two walking figures, Gary wakes near a heating atop a ten story building. He yawns, looks down at the st spies Bob and Budd.
GARY'S VIEW: a tiny Bob and Budd are making their way acr field.
Hey, Scottie, here comes that fat  pig himself!!! He owes me money! Scottie, atop an adjacent building peeks his head over th The two guys are relatively close to one another but far street.
You know, the fat one... Pigeon!
He stole my shoes, the dick!
Hey, everybody, here comes Bob the  chiseler! He yells to the other buildings and other street kids to Scottie pours an old paper cup of Coca-Cola over Bob and below.
Bob hears the show atop the buildings.
Ah, I think my friends can see I  am back from Boise. Bob looks worried and happy at the same time, not knowing are friend or foe. He shields himself from the Coke sprin
Do you see any clouds in the sky,  Budd?
Budd and Bob enter the threshold of a busted up but opera hotel. There is a fire in a trashcan turned upside down, holes poked in it.
Is Jane Lightwork alive, Bob? BOB
She must be old, she has no  choice...
THE TWO sit at a larger fire deeper into the derelict hot
I remember her daughter, she died  years ago... of old age. She must  be old, all right. That was before  I came to Clements Inn. BOB
Jesus... the things that we've  seen. Aren't I right, Bob? Aren't  I right?
We have seen the light at the end  of the tunnel...

That we have, that we have... in  fact Bob, we have. Jesus... the  things that we've seen. Scott drinks from a beer can inside the derelict hotel, t to a young boy, laughs, wipes his mouth and puts his lit  cigarette into the mouth of Gary, making his way to some through a circle of girls, kisses Denise, who we remember the Broadway Cafe, and charges up the steps.
Inside the hotel on a staircase landing, Scottie passes a of figures, one is asleep and one is awake.
And he's snoring like a horse.

head_text.subj: SCOTTIE OPENS A DOOR AT THE TOP OF THE STEPS AND WALKS IN
ROOM, INTERRUPTING MIKE, WHO STANDS OVER BOB'S SNORING BO

text: Mike coolly holds up a wad of bills and a folded envelope cocaine.
Scottie takes the cocaine from him, sits down at the foot bed and begins to unfold the packet. Bob turns in the bed rush of air from the sheets blows the white powder out of packet.
(climbing in bed with Bob) What do you care? Bob, dazed, is looking around himself, like he is being h

(amusing Mike) Why, you wouldn't even look at a  clock, unless hours were lines of  coke, dials looked like the signs of  gay bars, or time itself was a fair  hustler in black leather... isn't  that right, dude? Bob staggers out of bed retching and spitting. Then back waking stupor, feeling something is being put over on him
There's no reason to know the  time. We are timeless. Bob checks his wallet.
Aren't you forgetting, Scottie my  boy, [A GOVERNOR'S SON], that we  who steal, do so at midnight? Bob's money and cocaine are gone. Bob turns angry and bel
What the...who ripped me off?   Budd!!! Budd!!!
Budd stands at the stoop and comes through the door, Just is running out.
I fell asleep and have been  robbed!
Jane Lightwork, the owner of the established hotel, comes arms. She is very old.
You'd think that I could keep the  peace in my house...
Scott and Mike laugh. Mike gets down on his hands and kne tries to scoop up a little cocaine from the floor.
Bob, Bob we'll find your drugs.  We'll find them.
Bob is storming down it in a rage, people opening doors o rooms.
Jane, I know you well enough...
Hotel dwellers are watching Jane move down the hall answe Bob.
I know you, ~ you owe me money,  Bob, and now you pick a fight with  me, and are disturbing the peace  of my hotel.
MAIN derelict hall of the hotel.
Bob parades, in his night clothes, in front of a gatherin outcasts in the hotel.
This hotel is full of thieves...  Junkies!
LAUGHTER from the throngs of outcasts. Jane enters a balc overlook of the main hall. Mike and Scott enter, arms aro other, laughing.
It's impossible to board a dozen  or so men and women who live  honestly and have the others live  like Junkies.
One of the dwellers listening to the argument is shooting they speak. We see a close view of the needle and Bob run around in the background.
Bob makes his way next to Scott.
You have corrupted me, Scottie, I  was an innocent before I met you.  ..and now look at me.. just a  little better than wicked. I used  to be a virtuous man... Scottie is laughing at him.
'''well, virtuous enough. I swore  a little. I never gambled more  than seven times a week. Poker. I  never picked up a street boy more  than once a quarter... Scottie laughs. BOB
... of an hour. Bad company has  corrupted me. I'll be darned if I  haven't forgotten what the inside  of a church looks like.
Where do you find your strike  tonight, Bob?
I see a good change for Bob to  make. From Stealing to Preaching.
Stealing is my vocation, Scott.  It's not a sin for a man to labor  at his vocation. GARY

Very early tomorrow morning, there  will be small time rock and roll  promoters coming back from their  show. Every night, they walk home  with the loot and they stop by the  Grotto Bar, one mile away from  here, and more often than not  they've been drinking already. If  we can't steal from them on their  way to the bar, we can get them  when they come out. See, dude?
I'm not gonna rob anybody.  I'd  rather sell my ass. Straight and  simple. It's less risky.
So long as I don't know these guys  personally. ..it's okay with me.
They're from Beaverton. New to the  business... MIKE
Not me. I'm not going along on  this crackpot scheme. Especially  since Gary thought it up.
Come oft it, Mikey. Find a better  way to make a buck. Something to  fall back on, other than your ass. MIKE
Bob walks away from the two others.
(whispering) Come along, Mikey. I have a joke I  wanna play... a joke I can't pull  off alone...
Mike laughs and joins Bob, hugging him around his fat bel
Oh, my sweetheart, come and rob  with us tomorrow.
I was going to come anyway.
Provide for us, oh great  psychedelic Papa!
Scottie grabs Denise and kisses her then begins to leave the door. He throws her to Mike who catches her and runs her.
Good catch dude. ..and meet me on  three street!
Scott leaves, Bob follows him: 0utside the derelict hotel.
Scott. When you inherit your  fortune, on your twenty-first  birthday, let's see. ..how far  away is this? SCOTT
One week away, Bob, just one more  week.
Let's not call ourselves robbers,  but Diannah's foresters. Gentlemen  of the shade. Minions of the Moon.  Men of good government.

(under his breath) When I turn twenty-one, I don't want  any more of this life. My mother and  father will be surprised at the  incredible change. It will impress  them more when such a fuck up like  me turns good than if I had been a  good son all along. All the past  years I will think of as one big  vacation. At least it wasn't as  boring as schoolwork. All my bad  behavior I'm going to throw away to  pay my debt. I will change when  everybody expects it the least. Scott turns and leaves.
And you will become a hard roller,  a hatchet man for your old man.
Scott laughs to himself, because he knows Bob is misunder him. Bob is part of the past life that he says he is goin throw away.
No! You will be the hatchet man,  Bob, that will be your job, and so  there will rarely be a job  hatcheted. It will be one big  endless party, won't it?
Bob laughs. Scott walks across a field.
Well, at least my little friend  has offered me a job. They are so  good to me.
Denise and Mike hang out together. Both are smoking cigar which have made a billow of smoke that hangs over the tab is in the front window.
Moms are great, because, you know,  I could always go to my mom and  say, hey I need a new lipstick,  and she would always give me money  for that. That was great. MIKE
I only saw my mom once, but I  remember what she looked like. She  was very beautiful. DENISE
How could you remember when that  god-awful thing happened? MIKE
Dunno. But I remember it. how  beautiful and kind she good. Yeah,  I remember was. She was good DENISE
And she split from you, huh?
Did you see what was going on,  Mike? Between Pinky and Dale? Did  you see that? That's the third  fight I've seen today. Things  always happen in threes. MIKE
I don't know. They have a sort of,  ah, relationship. Between them.
Across the street there are three people, a TALL MAN, who hat stuck on his boot and a lady and another man with a d leash.
I don't know about that, but, ah,  listen, what you and me talk  about, it's just between us, you  understand? Hey, what's over  there, see those assholes? Who are  they, you know any of them?

head_text.subj: DENISE STANDS AND OPENS THE FRONT DOOR AND YELLS ACROSS T

text: The group across the street look up and begin yelling bac we cannot hear them.
Mike and Denise kiss, and their arms are entangled in a l but awkward embrace. Twigs and leaves are caught in Denis as they are lying on the ground.
Different STILL COMPOSITIONS OF SEX while they are lying wilds under the bridge.
That reminds me, I gotta send my  Ma a Christmas card, I still  haven't done it yet. MIKE
Yeah, I haven't done it either.
Your mom lives in Idaho right now?
I used to live in Montana.
My own cousin. He's dead. that's  one...two... And my grandma, it  usually comes in threes. DENISE

My cousin died, my grandmother  died, and right after she died,  her daughter died. My aunt. Within  a year. And they wuz all women,  not even a year, six...well....  six months-eight months, three  women in the family died.
That's funny, huh? I WONDER WHY  YOU THOUGHT THAT, cuz, my FATHER  says stuff like that. DENISE
My father told me that, said  things usually come in threes...  and I said, .... you're crazy.
A Long pause. A motorcycle passes, someone yells, and a h honks.
It sounds crazy. That's my lucky  number too.
You know why I like eight?

Cause of the eight ball. You know.  When you're stuck behind the eight  ball? I fuckin' feel stuck behind  the eight ball today, I'll tell  you. The business is so slow in the  middle of the week, you know that  Mike?
Mike empties the contents of his pockets at a bathroom si has in his possession: One condom. One comb with blond ha in it. One nickel. Half a stick of gum. One knife with th W stamped on it.

He arranges these things in a neat order on the surface o sink while a man flushes a toilet in the background and u another sink. Mike is quite at home here. He takes his ti arranging the articles, and washing his hands. He looks o the man washing his hands and gives him a friendly smile.

The man leaves. Mike puts all the things on the sink into pockets. Then he walks over to a urinal, unzips his fly a starts to take a leak. A shadow opens the door in back of and without turning around, Mike senses the presence of a Alleyway. Night.
Scottie is helping Bob with a disguise, putting on pants large belly, with medallions around the neck.
How long has it been, Bob, since  you could see your own feet?
About four years, Scottie. Four  years of grief. It blows a man up  like a balloon. Mike and Budd appear, running, with costumes on. There ar others behind them.
There's rock and roll money  walking this way!
And they're drunk as skunks. MIKE
This is going to be easy. We can  do it lying down. SCOTT
But don't fall asleep, now, Mike.
You four should head them off  there!
We four? How many are walking with  them?
Huh, shouldn't they be robbing us?
Scottie laughs. Bob waddles along the side of the alleywa stepping on a curb, then in a pothole losing his balance. accomplice whistles from atop a building. We SEE the grou ROCK AND ROLL promoters.
Bob walks further from Mike and Scottie.
If they escape from you, we'll get  them here.
Eight feet of cobblestones is like  30 yards of flat road with me. Mike and Scott run off, laughing at him.
I can't see a damned thing in  here.
Jesus, will you shut up! And keep  on your toes! Budd sees the promoters coming and waves to Bob as he lie on the ground.
Lie down and stay quiet, until  they round the corner and we'll  ambush them. BOB
Have you got a crane to lift me up  again?
Down the way, the rock and roll promoters are approaching no knowledge of the buffoonery at the other end of the tu alleyway. They are drunk.
Come along neighbor, Tommy will  lead the way. I've lost track of  time... (burp)
At the other end of the alley:
Bob and three others are marching in procession, chanting facsimile of Rashneesh, but a bad act.
The rock promoters approach, smashing a bottle.
Scottie and Mike hide behind garbage cans, laughing.
The rock promoters circle the group of chanting Rashneesh
I thought that all you Rashneesh  had up and left...
Victim 1 pours a beer on one of their heads. Just as he d Bob pulls out two long pistols, almost heavy enough that cannot hold them straight, barrels parallel.
Aha! One move and I'll blow you  away, you sully scumbags, up  against that wall!
One of the victims falls down and begins to run away. One Bob's men starts after him. A lockbox that he was carryin to the ground. Bob spies it.
Bob aims one pistol at the running figure as he keeps the against the wall with the other pistol. He fires three ti of Bob's boys grabs the lockbox.
A VIEW of the running figure, bullets cutting around him.
Bob winks at the lockbox and shoots the gun in the air.
All the rock promoters go running. Bob charges after them the gun twice more in the air, then once at the lockbox, it open.
The valise is open. Let's see what  we got.
Mike and Scottie hiding behind trashcans.
Where are our disguises? Mike runs to his stash and finds two large capes and larg They put these on.
Bob finds wads of money and receipts.
Ticket anyone? To next week's  show?
He throws these on the ground and the boys fall over them for the tickets. Bob wads the money and puts it back in t laughing to himself.
Mike and Scottie sneak closer to the group still hiding, flowing capes concealing their identity.
Scott and Mike have disappeared,  did the shots scare them away?
They sneak closer. Mike lights a big firecracker and wait
...maybe we should get the hell  out of here. But, are they such  chickens?
Mike and Scottie, disguised, jump out with large silver b bats, swinging them and making as much noise as they can, knocking over a set of garbage cans, flashing flashlights Bob and the others' eyes.
Frightened, Bob drops the lockbox and runs, the others fo Mike and Scottie hitting them with the bats as they go.
Mike swings the bat at Bob, it grazes the side of a build sparks fly from it. Bob wheezes from the run.
Scottie chases the others in the same direction.
They stand, kicking garbage cans and watching them run,  convulsing with laughter.
Bob Pigeon will sweat to death!
Jack Favor enters the Governor's CHAMBERS day.
Can anyone tell me about my son?
It's been a full three months  since I last saw him. Where is my  son Scott? AID

Ask around in Old Town, in some of  the taverns there. Some say he  frequently is seen down there  drinking with street denizens.  Some who they say even rob our  citizens and store owners. I can't  believe that such an effeminate  boy supports such 'friends.'
A high overhead (helicopter?) view of the country landsca the early morning. Far below us on a lonely road is a sma a motorcycle, traveling east.
Further along on its travels, the motorcycle crosses a st BRIDGE.
Old Town day. Scottie and Mike, riding on a stolen motorcycle, sweep th the early morning streets without being noticed.
Stopping at a stop light in the city.
Mikey, do you realize how long I  have been here out on the streets,  on this crusade? MIKE
About as long as the rest of us. I  mean. I can't even remember that  far back, Scott, I mean
Wow... that's a really long time,  Scott. Have I been here three  years, too?
What I'm getting at, Mike, is that  we are survivors.
Yeah, well, so, isn't that  obvious?
Yes. It is incredibly obvious.  They could drop a bomb on this  city and you know what we would  do?
No. We would survive. Because we  are...
Say, Scott. Whaddya say we go  survive over at the Broadway Cafe  a little bit, at least it's warm  over there.
Mike and Scott sit around the table with Carl and Mary. M blows a smoke ring.
Denise runs in the door of the cafe, excited about someth
MIKE! Scottie! There's a man from  City Hall down the street. He  wants to speak with you, Scottie.
He says that he's sent by your  father.
Say hello and send him to my  mother.
What kind of a man is it?
A young man. And he's got cops  with him.
Two POLICEMEN and one OFFICIAL are walking down the stree the Broadway cafe.
The cops enter, passing The PROPRIETOR of the cafe, an ag heavyset woman named NANCY.
How are you this morning, NANCY?  Don't mind if we take a look  around your place, do you? One officer is already inspecting the stolen motorcycle o
Mike sees this, and looks the other way from the cop who peering in the Broadway cafe window.
Have you seen the young Scott  Favor?
I do believe he was here just a  second ago. Nancy looks in the  front window. NANCY
Scott is giving Denise a long kiss, hiding from the cops. OFFICIAL walks to the front window of the Cafe.  Scott pr he is being rudely interrupted.
Excuse me... Mr. Favor... we have  been sent in search of a fat  man... a large bearded.... COP 1
What do you want with him?
Ahem. There's been a report, sir,  he has been involved in a  holdup...
Last night. Have you seen him?
I saw him around last night, when  was the holdup?
I saw him about four, but he  wasn't very loose with his wallet.  Did he get away with any of the  money?
Yes, indeed, sir... two thousand  dollars of a rock promoter's  money.
Well, anyway, I haven't seen him  recently. Why do you look here?
They say he has friends here.
Sorry for the interruption. We  have a message for you from your  father. He says that he would like  to see you as soon as possible.

head_text.subj: THE OFFICIAL HANDS SCOTT AN ENVELOPE.

text: Scott takes the envelope and puts it on the table.
Let's not get Favor's kid involved  in this report if we can help it.  But if he were my son, I'd.... Cop 1 makes a fist and slams It In the palm of his other
Bob is a wanted man now.
And as dangerous to be around as  cops themselves.
Mike suddenly begins to shake, and, falls asleep.
Scottie picks up the envelope from his father and puts it pocket.
Mike and Scott are stuck on a long straight road in the d Mike is angry at Scott because he doesn't think he knows motorcycle works.
Scott is trying again and again to start the engine.
He tries to turn it over again.

If I had known that it was going  to be this hard to start, then I  wouldn't have stopped it at all. Mike looks at the road and the surrounding area. It is th road that he was stuck on in the beginning.
Scott? I just know that I have  been on this road before.
Mike stares at the face in the road. Two cactus for eyes, mountains for hair, a cloud shadow forms the mouth over a nose road with a dotted line running down it.
At night, Scott and Mike sit next to a fire they have mad side of the road.  We can hear Indians in the distance da and chanting a song.
It sure is lonely out in the  desert.
If I had had a normal family, and  a good upbringing, then I would  have been a well adjusted person.  But somehow that just didn't work  out.
Well, normal, you know, with a mom  and a dad and a dog and shit like  that... normal.
So you didn't have a dog?  Or you  didn't have a dad...
I didn't have a dog and I didn't  have a dad. Well, not a normal  dad...
The music is getting louder. It sounds like a war chant.
Mike is hesitating.  He is about to say something persona looks at Scott and back to the fire, a few times too many
Scott is getting Mike's drift. Mike rubs his crotch.
I mean, don't you ever get horny?
Oh, yeah... not for a guy.
Mike.  Two guys can't love each  other.  They can only be friends.
An awkward moment passes where Mike is looking away from and Scott can't help but look at Mike.  Then Scott catche eye and motions for him to come closer to him.
Mike walks over to Scott and Scott holds him in his arms.
Overhead VIEW of the two in front of the campfire.
I only have sex for money.
Mike starts to get out some money.
But we can be close friends.
The next morning. Mike is sleeping. As he opens his eyes, see Scott still trying to start the motorcycle.
Mike stands and looks down the road at an approaching Sta Police Car. Mike, afraid of the police, starts to move in bushes.
Scott is out of breath trying to start the bike.
Scott looks in the direction of the police car.
Scott hits the side of the gas tank of the bike with the his hand.
Can't get the bike started. Cops  are coming. Stuck in the middle of  nowhere with a stolen bike. Yeah,  Mike. Looks like this is the end.
The policeman pulls up to them and parks.
The policeman sits in his car for a second and reports in radio, then he gets out and walks over to the boys.
Mike gets scared and runs into the desert.
The cop stands and watches. Mike has nowhere to go, he is into an open desert.
The policeman, a full blooded American Indian, seems amus his power. He looks at Scott then back at Mike, who trips desert and falls in a cloud of dust.
I don't know. I guess he doesn't  like cops.
What are you kids doing out here?
This cycle is one bitch to turn  over. But you probably don't know  about motorcycles. You aren't a  motorcycle cop.
Scott walks through the desert looking for Mike where he He picks him up out of the dirt, spit dripping from his s lips, and smacks him in the face.
Wake up, Mikey, the heat's off.
When Mike wakes up. He is inside a TRAILER at night.
Scott is eating sandwiches to his right that are on a lit tray.

There is MIKE'S BROTHER leaning into him on his left. He Mike offensively. His brother is very good looking, but l like he has lost his mind somewhere down the line. Which he lives in the desert in a trailer, away from people.

Your mother... now she was a right  woman. She used to be so proud of  you... you know... she would just  beam. And not Jim Beam either. If  you know what I mean. We used to  drive for hours to get a look at  you. I remember, what was it...  eighteen years ago? MIKE

Is that how old you are now? I  thought you wuz younger than  that... what? Well anyway, we  would start off in the morning to  see you, and it would take an hour  to get to the institution. You  were maybe one year old. What?  I  wasn't proud that you had to live  in an institution, mind you... but  all the same, when I would look at  you, all the institutional walls  would come down and we were a  family. Your mom, me, and you. God  knows where dad was.
Mike is getting visibly upset. Scott gets up to go to the bathroom.
Scott enters and notices a velvet portrait of a woman han the wall. Off screen Scott can hear Mike and his Brother.
I don't belong to you, DUDE... I'm  not yours...
(his voice booms out so  unexpectedly deep and loud that  Scott is startled) Shut your  mouth! Don't you talk back...
His brother hits the table with a crash.

Well... (takes a breath ) Anyway. You were maybe not in the  biological sense, my brother, but in  our business, ~..... (holds his  hands up in the air) And If I'm not  Your brother, how's come you turned  out exactly like me then?
Mike has gotten the jitters and fallen asleep in front of
Oh, he'll come out or it. It's  like this whenever we get together   It's always like this when we get  together  It's the way that we say  hello to each other.
I'm all that he's got. But he  doesn't want me. He doesn't care.  He'd rather live out on the  streets. I love him, though.
Scott looks around the trailer at all the velvet portrait hanging on the walls.
Oh. I paint these for a living.  But sometimes the people don't  send the check when they get  finished. So I keep them. I like  them.
Mike and his brother sip iced tea. Colored lights decorat trailer.
Want me to tell you what happened  to your Mom? Have you ever heard  it? Did you ever hear what the  hell happened to her?
No. But I don't care. BROTHER
You loved her, and don't tell know  you did. me you didn't. I
I already heard what happened to  her.
But you don't know the whole  story. One thing about the truth.  It's interesting.

If you had known her, you would  care. She would see guys on the  side. At night. When I wouldn't be  around... maybe I'd be in San  Francisco or some darned place,  doing my own business. God knows  where. She would see guys...  yeah.... anyway   along comes this  guy. A guy we both knew. A guy who  was into cards. A gamblin' man.  And he said that he used to herd  cattle in Argentina. I dunno,  maybe he did, and he had a bit of  money. More'n I had at that point  in time. But it was funny, the way  he gambled. He was not safe in the  friends that he made. So his money  would come and go real fast.... MIKE
I never heard this one before.

So this guy, your Mom fell for.  What? She went cuckoo over this  guy. Well, their affair went on  for a year or so and your mom  wanted to marry this guy. She was  already married to our real dad.  So he said no. He didn't love her  anyways. But she wanted him to  marry her. And to have a little  family. That's when you were born.  As a matter of fact, you were  really the cause of this whole  mess. She wanted to make a little  family and take you and this guy  someplace and set something up.
A family thing! Ridiculous, right. A  card man. Had a bunch of money, but  could have just as well lost it on  his next hand. Probably did too. Well  you'll see what I'm getting at.
That's not how I heard it.

Yeah, I know. You heard it from me  and I'm telling it different this  time, see? So this Mom of yours  found herself a fuckin' gun. I  thought she was going to blow me  away with it one night. She got so  into this gun. She would flash it  to anybody that gave her trouble.  She would sleep with it. Yeah...  strange, huh? She would stir fry  vegetables with the loaded gun.  What? I mean    What? I used to  say, politely, "Mom, don't go  stirring up dinner with the gun,  now, you'll blow a hole in the  frying pan." What?

And she used to do other things  with this gun. Sexy things with  it. Oh, boy, she was into this  thing. I just thought it was some  sort of weird phase that she was  going through. And so anyway, this  guy, who she was cuckoo over,  brought her to the movies one  night. A drive-in movie in a  stolen car, don't-chaknow, what?  And the movie was.... ah.... RIO  BRAVO or some shit like that. And  well, she went and shot this  guy.... don't-cha-know.
You're making this up as you go  along, bro.
And they didn't find him until the  next show, RIO BRAVO playing on  the big screen. Spilled popcorn  soaking up the blood.
Mike begins to really cry now, bawling and coughing.
(who has been listening)  Oh, come on, how corny, man....
No. Your mom had to split, and  split she did. And that guy. That  guy was your real father.
I knew that was coming. You sure  do like to make me cry, bro.
And I got this card from her, not  too awful long ago. Maybe a year.

Mike's Brother hands him a postcard with a Holiday Inn mo the front of it. Written on the card, Mike's mom says she working as a waitress there, in the "Blue Room" of the Ho Inn off Interstate 85 outside Boise, Idaho. He also hands picture of his mom.
Mike and Scott wore sunglasses as they journeyed onward t Blue Room, Scott driving the motorcycle and Mike riding o back.
Night time exterior of the Holiday Inn.
Mike and Scott pull up on the motorcycle and park it.
A hostess is standing in front of a sign that bills "Shec Crude" as the featured entertainer of the evening in the Room."
Mike is speaking to the hostess. He shows her his picture
My mother works here. Her name is  Dorothy.
(thinks for a second) No. I can't think of anyone by that  name. Let me get the manager.
The hostess picks up the phone.
A MANAGER is sitting behind his desk wearing a shiny blue he shifts in his swiveling chair, and looks at the Holida Postcard that Mike's mother sent to his father.
Dorothy, Dorothy   There was a  Dorothy Biondi used to work here a  year ago, but she split. Saved up  all her money and headed to Italy.
Yeah. It took her forever to save  any cash, but she did, and flew  away. She was looking for her  family. I guess she came from  Italy. But she didn't look  Italian.
I don't know.   I guess that she  was.
In the lobby of the Holiday Inn at night.
Mike and Scott witness the arrival of the German Mercedes parts salesman.
The guy who gave us a ride from  Portland. What's he doing here?
Scott and Mike walk up to him. HANS turns and a broad smi crosses his face.
Mike! Scottie! How good to run  into you! My dear boys! How have  you been? Inside Hans' hotel bathroom. Night.
Mike lies in a bathtub in sudsy water. There is a poundin bathroom door.
I just got in the tub! Wait your  turn.
But Mike! Don't you want anything  to eat? We are ordering room  service. Ya?
Ahhh.  Room service?  Ya!  Let me  see. Two hamburgers, with cheese,  onions, lettuce, tomato, no  pickles. A Coke and french fries. HANS
O.K. That's hamburger wiz  everything, no pickles, Coke,  french fries.
As Mike and Scott eat their hamburgers, Hans sits across them next to a small desk light on a double bed in his Ho Inn room.
Good, Hans. I don't think that  I've tasted a hamburger as fine as  this Holiday Inn hamburger.
I'm glad that you like it.
How did you boys get so far? I  only left you in Portland a few  days ago. SCOTT
We rode on our trusty motorcycle.
And what brings you to the Holiday  Inn?
Still images of Mike, Scott and Hans having sex in the mo
Hans rides his newly purchased motorcycle across the plai Boise to Picabu, Idaho. A local policeman pulls him over mph in a 45 mph zone.
At the Boise Airport Scott and Mike stand in a ticket lin ticket taker stamps their tickets.
Mike and Scott shake their heads no. ItaliA

Mike wakes up and finds himself sitting beside the Trevi in Rome. There are other street kids surrounding him fish coins that tourists have thrown in the fountain. He doesn Scott. He looks around a bit.
Mike's VIEW of Scott in a taxi cab.
The TAXI pulls up to a small farmhouse on a hill outside Mike and Scott get out and walk around the house. A farme cutting his crop on the next hillside.
A DOG walks up to them.
The taxi driver gets out of the car and asks for his mone Italian. Scott holds out the money that he has and the dr takes it, counting it out for himself.
Mike walks around a corner of the house and notices the d open as the cab drives off down the drive.
Scott sits down on the stoop in front of a shack and Mike into the house.

An extremely Beautiful Italian girl walks around the corn Scott is sitting. He can't see her. And she leans against shack and stares at him, then looks up at Mike, who is wa through the house trying to find someone.
The girl is a little shy and leans on the shack.
No. This isn't my house, but. It  is my uncle's house.
And he is Mike. We came from  America to find his mother.
Yes, but. It is not true that she  lives here..
No. She left a long time ago. Back  to America.
Oh, shit.  Was she your friend?
I wanted to speak English, and she  taught it to me.
Scott looks up at her, a little surprised.
Mike walks from the house to Scott and Carmella.
Later in the afternoon, Mike is inside of a room in the h and he is crying. He is talking to Scottie, who is holdin
I mean, Christ, we come all this  fuckin' way and she ain't here  either. Where'd she go from here?
Mike walks through the rooms of the Italian country
MIKE'S VIEW of a room, and Scott is just closing the door winks at Mike as he shuts it.
Inside the room, Carmella and Scott lay down on the bed a
Scott takes off his clothes and ravishes Carmella, tearin dress.
Carmella is naked and the two grab and twist with each ot the white bed.
Mike in the country, watching the farmer in the field.
Mike approaches the house and there is a taxi cab waiting Carmella is putting a suitcase in the trunk.
Scott helps Carmella in the front seat of the taxi.
Hey, Mike. Let me talk with you  for a second.
Scott follows Mike inside the house and into a room.
I'm gonna take some time off.
Scott gives Mike an American Express card.
Don't leave home without it. Ha- ha. (Mike doesn't think it's  funny) I mean, maybe I'll run into you  down           the road.
Mike is shocked but sees what Scott needs to do as he loo the window and can see Carmella in the taxi.
I'll be okay. Don't worry about  me.
No, man, forget it. Hurry up,  she's waiting, you're gonna lose  her.
All right. You sure you'll be  okay? MIKE
Go on, get out of here.
Outside, a dog watches the taxi leave down a rutted dirt
Well. So much for the great  protector-of-us-all. Protector of  himself, more like. I couldn't  believe Scott would leave me here  in the middle of a foreign  country.
Inside, Mike goes into one of his fits, snorting, a littl pig, and falls asleep.
Mike wakes up in an airline's passenger seat. A STEWARDES leaning over him.
Wake up. Wake up, we're here.
INT. BROADWAY CAFE in the day.
Mike sits at the round table in front of the window.
Denise is with a new boy, STUART, and they are making out sits and chain smokes cigarettes, there are three other U around the table.
And so, I was back in Portland,  enjoying the life I used to lead.  It was like I was back from a  vacation. Denise had a boyfriend  now.... Ext. street night.
Cars cruise by. Mike is on a street corner. He hops into stranger's car.
Still views of Mike having sex with a date.
... and I enjoyed the fruits of my  labor.
CLOSE VIEW of money exchanging hands.
Mike is at the table again, smoking a cigarette.
There are three new kids who look very MEAN, and are hass another kid, pulling his collar and throwing him around.
And there were new kids who were  coming around who wanted to take  your money. It was a dark period  for the streets. Normally, Scott  would keep order In the Broadway  Cafe.
A Hot dog stand. Gary cheerfully prepares Mike a hot dog.
Gary and Ray both got work at  stands. It was funny...
Ray serves Mike a hot dog.
( they both sold hot dogs. Which  is what they were used to selling  on the streets in the old days.  These guys had really changed, I  thought. Mike's FACE, outdoors in the daytime.
He looks out on the cityscape.
The buildings of the city uproot and tumble in the air.

Mike wakes up.  He is sitting next to Bob and Budd. A new a colorfully dressed man named BAD GEORGE, who looks like street minstrel, talks on the street in front of a fancy  restaurant.  Bad George is obnoxiously yelling in Bob's f
Bob! What tidings I bring you. And  such joy. Some of that old rot gut  that you and I used to drink. I  have three bottles stashed in the  bushes out on eighty-second.
Think of the fun we can have, if  we could only rind a ride for a  journey to the bushes where the  hooch is hid.
If I shared your wine, I might  catch this awful disease you  appear to have. My clothes would  turn striped, and I would suddenly  have bells on my toes, like this  here...
Bob points to George's bells on his shoes.
Bob, you're one of the greatest  living men on Three-street.
Surely you can find us a ride  somewhere.

As I listened to Bad George and  Bob talk, I watched across the  street as a long black car pulled  up alongside one of the fancier  restaurant/bar establishments of  Portland. And who got out of that  car? It was the old protector-of- us-all, himself Scottie Favor.
Bob notices the group of men getting out of a car in fron restaurant. One of them is Scottie , in a three pieced su is with his Italian girlfriend.
If it isn't Scottie Favor himself.  Blessed are they who have been my  close friends. Now dressed in a  three pieced suit and looking  every bit a gentleman! He has run  into his inheritance.
George, Budd, Mike. We have waited  for this day to come.
Bob charges in the direction of Scottie and his friends.

Scottie and his associates, who are men much older than h perhaps in their thirties, make their way through the yup crowd standing in the bar drinking. Hellos and how-do-you are directed at Scottie. A man stops Scott on his way thr crowd.
Scottie! I haven't seen you in a  dog's age. You're looking well. So  grown up. Scottie, I'd like you to  meet Ed Warren, he's in marketing  at Nike. Ed, this is Scottie  Favor.
Oh, Jack Favor's son, hello,  pleased to meet you.
Bob is following Scottie through the crowd. Scottie walks Hans, who is having a drink with another man. They recogn other but neither speak.
Bob, with Bad George in tow, straightens himself up as th crowd looks on disapprovingly. Their smelly clothing betr them.
Come, George, watch this. You will  see the attention that I get.
Bob looks at his clothes. A bouncer spots them.
It's true we're drawing attention  to ourselves. But Scottie will see  that I am dying to see him, and it  won't matter how we're dressed.
Scotty and his friends are sitting around a crowded table they take their seats, Scottie hears Bob bellowing.
VIEW of Bob being detained by the bouncer.
God save you! God save you, my  sweet boy.
Scotty turns away from Bob, so his back is to him.
Silence for a second, the crowd grows quieter.
I mean you, Sonny! It's me, Bob! Without turning toward Bob, Scottie speaks.
I don't know you, old man.
Scottie turns and meets Bob, who kneels next to him.
Bob is thinking that Scottie's attitude is a joke.
Don't think that I'm the same  Scottie that I was before.  Everyone has noticed that I have  turned away from that life, and  the people who kept me company. Bob is shocked.
Outside, Mike can see through the windows of the restaura and Scottie talking.

When I was young, and you were my  street tutor. An instigator for my  bad behavior, I was trying to  change. Now that I have, and until  I change back   don't come near  me. Bob feels the rejection like a shock. Stares at Scott for second, then he's pulled away by the bouncer.
Mike watches Bob and Budd sit down with him.
Don't take all this seriously.  It's one of his jokes.
Nighttime overhead view of Bob in his greasy derelict hot He is having nightmares, and suddenly he CRIES OUT'
Mike awakes atop a downtown building.
Mike enters, and walks through a very quiet, although cro MAIN ENTRANCE. There is a body on a slab in the middle of room that is covered with a sheet.
He's gone now, either to Heaven or  to Hell.

Be sure it isn't to Hell. He tried  to be an honest sort. I'm the one  who heard him cry out last night.  He said God, God, God... three or  four times. And when I got there I  put my hand into the bed and felt  his feet. And they were cold as  stone. And I checked the rest of  his body. And it too was as cold  as stone. BUDD
I guess you're gonna miss him the  most, Budd.
Mike gives him Scottie's American Express card, as others his body out of the hotel. Dawn views of the city.
Here. Maybe you can give him a  good burial.
In the country, Mike looks at the road.
He has visions of sagebrush and rock flying into the air picked up by a big wind.
Then he lies asleep by the side of the road.
I suppose that a lot of kids like  me think that they have no home,  that home is a place where you  have a mom and a dad.

But home can be any place that you  want. Or wherever you can find    My home is right here on the side  of this road, that I been to  before. I just know I been on this  fucking road one time before, you  know that? Later, a car drives by Mike's sleeping body by the side o road. It turns around and stops next to Mike. A figure pu in his car and drives off down the road.

Sometimes I had thought that God  had not smiled on me, and had  given me a bum deal. And other  times, I had thought that God had  smiled on me. Like now. He was  smiling on me... for the time  being....
Scott is driving the car. He looks over at Mike sleeping.
The car disappears down the road.
